page.title: 13Invermoriston:Customs.
page.content: Hallowe'en. October31 is anticipated with excitement. Housewives lay in stocks of apples,nuts,and sweets and sometimes bake biscuits in appropriate shapes of witches' "familiars"in preparation for visits from the "guisers". Children devise costumes which concealtheir identity,put on masks and set out after dark with turnip lantern or torch on a round of as many houses as possible.Aknock at the door may be the guisers or the house holder may find no one there at all! Once inside the guisers entertain with song or poem in return for apples and nuts. In school they will have made decorationswith Hallowe'en symbols; witches,bats,ghosts etc. After guising is over the children may gather at one house and "dook"for apples .
